thread.title: Kyle Shanahan officially in as 49ers' head coach
thread.title_full: Kyle Shanahan officially in as 49ers' head coach

title: Kyle Shanahan officially in as 49ers' head coach
text:
Let friends in your social network know what you are reading about Facebook Email Kyle Shanahan officially in as 49ers' head coach One of the NFL's worst-kept secrets is now out in the open. Post to Facebook Kyle Shanahan officially in as 49ers' head coach One of the NFL's worst-kept secrets is now out in the open. Check out this story on USATODAY.com: http://usat.ly/2jW0vsJ Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Join the Nation's Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Kyle Shanahan officially in as 49ers' head coach USA TODAY Sports Published 7:18 p.m. ET Feb. 6, 2017 | Updated 6 minutes ago Atlanta Falcons offensive coordinator Kyle Shanahan is shown on the sideline in the third quarter of their game against the Minnesota Vikings at the Georgia Dome. (Photo: Jason Getz, USA TODAY Sports) CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
One of the NFL's worst-kept secrets is now out in the open: Kyle Shanahan is the new coach of the San Francisco 49ers. 
The Atlanta Falcons offensive coordinator officially agreed to terms Monday for the top job in San Francisco on Monday, the day after his team's 34-28 overtime loss to the New England Patriots in Super Bowl LI. Shanahan could not officially be hired until the completion of the Falcons' season. 
“It is truly an honor to be named head coach of the San Francisco 49ers, one of the marquee franchises in all of sports,” Shanahan said in a statement. “I must thank (49ers CEO) Jed and the York family for entrusting me with this great privilege and tremendous opportunity. I would also like to express my gratitude to Arthur Blank, Dan Quinn and the Atlanta Falcons organization for their support and the experience of a lifetime." 
MORE COVERAGE: 10 NFL offseason story lines to watch: Where does Tony Romo land? 
Shanahan had long been expected to fill the NFL's only remaining coaching vacancy. He joins new general manager John Lynch, who last Sunday was revealed as the San Francisco's choice for the position despite having no prior front-office experience. 
“The San Francisco 49ers are very fortunate to be able to bring in a coach of the caliber of Kyle Shanahan,” Lynch said in a statement. “As an offensive mind, I think he stands alone in the National Football League, as evidenced by the explosive and record-setting offense in Atlanta. Though he grew up around coaching, what has most impressed me about Kyle is that he’s become his own man in the profession. Our philosophies on football and our visions for leading the 49ers back to being a championship team align in every way. I am thrilled to have Kyle Shanahan on board.” 
In Atlanta, Shanahan engineered the league's high-scoring offense. Now he'll be tasked with reviving a San Francisco attack that ranked 31st in total yards last season. 
The hire is the third in as many years for the 49ers, as Chip Kelly and Jim Tomsula were dismissed in the last two years after just one campaign each. 
PHOTOS: Best of Super Bowl LI Facebook Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Tom Brady hoists the Lombardi Trophy after the Patriots beat the Falcons to win Super Bowl LI. Brady and New England won 34-28 in the first-ever Super Bowl to go to overtime. Mark J. Rebilas, USA TODAY Sports Patriots quarterback Tom Brady hoists the Lombardi Trophy for the fifth time, most of any quarterback ever. Richard Mackson, USA TODAY Sports Winning the Super Bowl appears to be one of the rare things that can get Patriots head coach Bill Belichick to crack a smile. Daniel Powers, USA TODAY Sports Patriots owner Robert Kraft hoists the Lombardi Trophy. Mark J. Rebilas, USA TODAY Sports Patriots quarterback celebrates with coach Bill Belichick after winning their fifth Super Bowl title together. Matthew Emmons, USA TODAY Sports NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell greets Patriots coach Bill Belichick after the game. Bob Donnan, USA TODAY Sports Patriots linebacker Dont'a Hightower (54) celebrates with defensive coordinator Matt Patricia. Matthew Emmons, USA TODAY Sports Patriots receiver Julian Edelman celebrates. Kevin Jairaj, USA TODAY Sports Patriots offensive tackle Marcus Cannon celebrates with the Lombardi Trophy. Troy Taormina, USA TODAY Sports Patriots coach Bill Belichick, right, celebrates with receiver Danny Amendola. Mark J. Rebilas, USA TODAY Sports Tom Brady couldn't believe it either after becoming the first quarterback to win five Super Bowl titles. Richard Mackson, USA TODAY Sports Patriots running back James White (28) plunges into the end zone to score late in the fourth-quarter. Robert Deutsch, USA TODAY Sports Patriots running back James White celebrates his fourth-quarter touchdown run that helped tie the score.
